body_content.explanation:
past simple and past participle of 
imagine
to form or have a mental picture or idea of something:
examples: Imagine Robert Redford when he was young - that's what John looks like.
Imagine (that) you're eating ice cream - try to feel how cold it is.
Can you imagine how it feels to be blind?
She imagined herself sitting in her favourite chair back home.
They hadn't imagined (= expected) (that) it would be so difficult.
I can't imagine (= I really don't know) what he wants from us.

body_content.explanation: to believe that something is probably true:
examples: I imagine (that) he's under a lot of pressure at the moment.
I don't imagine (that) they have much money.

body_content.explanation: to think that something exists or is true, although in fact it is not real or true:
examples: "Did you hear a noise?" "No, you're imagining things/No, you must have imagined it."
I've never heard her criticize you - I think you imagine it.

body_content.explanation: used to express shock or surprise, often at someone else's behaviour:
examples: She got married at 16! Imagine that!
Imagine spending all that money on a coat!
You can't imagine what a mess the house was in after the party.
